course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Modern China
course.description: This general history course introduces students to Chinaâ€™s political, economic, social, and cultural life during the 19th and 20th centuries. A survey of major political, social, and cultural events and changes in China from the late-imperial period to the founding of the People's Republic of China. The course focuses on  dramatic changes in China in order to review how these changes have radically reshaped Chinese society, economy, politics, and culture.

reviews.author: HELLO:)
reviews.title: Modern China
reviews.comment_content:
This is the pre-reg course for GCS Year 1 student.

This course is about the general history of China between the 1830s to 1940s, in terms of the social, political, economic and cultural perspective.

Week 1: Intro+China before Opium War
Week 2-3: opium war
Week 4-6: foreign invasion of China
Week 6-7: Reforms
Week: 7-8: Revolution, Republic and warlords
Week: 9-10: Rise of nationalism
Week 11-12: Fascist KMT versus righteous CCP
Week 13: Second Sino-Jap War

The topic is for reference only as the schedule always lag behind and may not have time cover all the topics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For the lecture, there is no ppt provided but only lecture outline is given. You need to jot down what he is saying quickly as the content he has spoken is similar to the final exam question. The format of final exam is long essay questions.

There are four tutorial sessions and one question (similar to essay question) and the coverage of assigned reading will be provided to you in advance to think of. Each one  need to speak sth and discuss the question given. Every student will be appointed as a leader of discussion in at least one session of tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorial+one tutorial essay: 15+25%
Final exam: 60%

Attendance to all sessions of the tutorial is mandatory. I went to every lectures and tutorial sessions. You are allowed to send email for asking the marks and comment of the tutorial essay. I forgot to send the email so I didn't know all the marks in this course, finally get B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is required reading every week. The amount of assigned reading is quite heavy. You can choose either reading the Chinese version or English version as you can write in either Chinese or English.

There is no mid-term and group project, only one essay and exam are needed.

reviews.author: Gunfm1939
reviews.title: Just Jot notes and summarise what he said
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
-China before the Opium War (Traditional society+land/econ/social policies)
-The Opium War
-Foreign Invasion of China
-Reforms (underrated achievements)
-Revolution, Republic, and Warlords
-Rise of Nationalism (Double-edged sword)  
-â€œFascistâ€ KMT versus â€œRighteousâ€ CCP    
-The Second Sino-Japanese War&Civil War (He didnâ€™t have enough time to talk about them and so not included in the final exam)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Though some comment said it is hard to follow the tutor, I had no problem at all. Mr Hoâ€™s tone is clear, and he would summarise the main ideas in last lesson, or picked a student to do so when every lessons started.

He is more like a critic of Chinese history, he highlighted his objective of giving you a different view which official textbooks wonâ€™t tell. For example, he thought Britain wasnâ€™t that responsible for the Opium War solely, Lin Zexu and Sun Yixian werenâ€™t that intelligent and moral, Manzuâ€™s reforms werenâ€™t that Bad etc.

Most importantly, a lot of content he mentioned will be useful for the exam (For mine, 3 out of 5 exam questions allowed you to copy directly of what he had said). Therefore it is easy to guess the questions by summarising the notes (Eg Why Lin Zexu was more responsible for the Opium War, Why Treaty ports brought benefits and less harms to China, Why Chinaâ€™s sovereignty wasnâ€™t been infringed seriously...)

Majority of textbook content hold an opposite view with Mr Ho, so the examples and statistics in it maybe useful, but not for the arguments. Overall he is a professor with passion, care and definite view.
reviews.comment_grading:
For zoom semester, 60% for final exam, and 40% for 4 tutorial attendance (Which everyone is expected to get nearly full marks)

For the 4-hour final exam, there are 5 essay questions, and you only need to choose any 2 of them to answer in either English or Chinese. I wrote around 3000 words in english for each question, and got an A. He gave a hint that you had to compare the options given when there are words like â€˜moreâ€™ or â€˜betterâ€™ in the question.
reviews.comment_workload: Extremely flexible. You just need to present once at one of the tutorials (Summarisation of assigned textbook chapters), and speak out in all 4 tutorials. Attendance is needed for tutorials but not compulsory for the lectures. You may skip all of them if you have strong faith on own ability. However, I strongly suggest attending all of them which make your exam much simpler (I really copied 70-80% words from my jotted notes directly with minor adjustments LOL)

reviews.author: slothslover
reviews.title: Very good grade course with a nice professor
reviews.comment_content: The content talks about the Chinese history about Qing dynasty to the development of PRC. I think for those who have studied Chinese History in secondary school will take an advantage on it. The content basically is quite easy to catch up even if you missed the lecture. Some of the lectures were actually quite fun to discuss and talk about.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lawrence teaching was quite funny and he was very willing to meet students to talk about their assignments. Although students have claimed that they could not understand what he was talking on lessons, I think this was mainly because he like to add some of his judgement on historical events. he was really patient to answer students questions and concerns on the course. He also gave comments and give instructions to our assignments which I think it was quite helpful for Year 1 students. Meanwhile, he did not like students trapped by the exam-oriented mindset so better asked him for instructions clearly on the assignment. However, the main point is his PPT slides mostly comprised of pictures and photos which required students to jot down everything he said and mentioned.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good which i think it is not hard to get a pass.
Attendance 10%
Essay 40%
Exam Question 10%
Final Exam 10%

We used to get take the attendance but the TA was trapped in Mainland so the the attendance was omitted. I have got the essay for 94/100 and 92/100. For exam question I got 50/50 and final was unreleased. I thought I did not do a great job in my final but turned out got an A+ as a final grade. I think he has a quite good grading.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload really depending on when did you start your assignments. The course had a lot of readings but no need to read all of them. Only read those Lawrence pointed out during the lecture would be fine. Lawrence had actually gave instructions on the assignment quite early. If you start it early and complete it bit by bit, I think it would not be a very big concern as a Year 1 student. Since the lecture did not count attendance at last, you may actually skipped all the lectures and just watched them before the final exam.

reviews.author: rubywxq
reviews.title: If possible, don't choose this
reviews.comment_content: Normal stuff on Chinese history, as the name of the course suggests. Though it was supposed to cover contents from the opium war to 1949, the content before 1911 was stressed too much that the professor merely taught anything about post 1911 revolution era.
reviews.comment_teaching:
No PPT, the only note the professor gave us is a page of paper that contains some points covered in class. This means that if you missed a class there is hardly any chance you would get to know what was actually taught in class. Also, his view on history was quite different from any other sources I had read. Be prepared for odd points he put forward.
BTW, I think this is the reason why the attendance of this course was really low(imagine a class with  60+ quota and only 10-20 people attending the course).
reviews.comment_grading: Sucks. It is likely that he gave score according to whether you follow his points rather than giving reasonable, self explanatory answer for the problems. Some may not hate this method, but I do.
reviews.comment_workload: The only reasonable part for the course. Only an essay at the end of the semester. The readings are required but not necessary for the essay, since the professor do have his "special" view on history that differed from the required readings.

reviews.author: Juliana
reviews.title: Interesting Class
reviews.comment_content: The content of this class is very interesting. As a foreigner who has never studied Chinese history in depth, this class was fascinating for me - but I'm sure it was also fascinating to the Chinese students to re-learn their national history according to the professor's information/opinions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor can be hard to follow sometimes - he will break off into Chinese to explain a concept and leave non-Chinese students confused. He has no powerpoints, slides, or supporting material other than a note-sheet he will hand out intermittently with tiny little fragments of his lectures on there - they're useless if you miss a class. Basically, if you miss a class and don't have a friend there taking notes for you, you're screwed.
However, it's clear that the professor really cares about the material, and he endeavors to answer every question thoroughly (although not necessarily concisely).
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was a bit of a mystery to me. The only grades we received were for 3 discussions, one midterm, and one final. We had received 0 grades for anything by the time we had written 2 of the discussions - this was upsetting as it gave us no way to know how well/poorly we had done, if we needed to improve or not. It was often not very clear what the professor wanted us to deliver - he would say we just needed to spend 20-30 minutes writing a quick response to the discussion questions, and then such answers received very low grades. This was confusing and frustrating at first, but once I figured this out, I did better.
My final grade in the class was a B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload was moderately heavy - lots of very dense readings, memorizing, and more more moreeee reading.
However, if you're an idiot (like me) you can put off the readings until right before the exam, cram everything into a final few days of frantic reading and studying, and it's not totally impossible that you'll do well :) -- but don't do this. Actually go to lecture! It's interesting and worthwhile. Read the readings when they are assigned so you don't get screwed during exams. Then you will be totally fine.

reviews.author: Zixin
reviews.comment_content:
This course is about modern Chinese history (1800s-1949).
The professor covers some main historical events like the Opium war, the 1911 revolution as well as the living status of Chinese people in that period.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ho's teaching style is no doubt unique: some may find it intriguing, while some others would easily fall asleep on his lecture. Unlike history teachers in high school who focus on memorizing historical events, he tends to teach us by giving statistics and some stories. This means that we would have to go through the textbook ourselves to have the basic concept and timeline of major events. But still, for those who are bored with high school history class and want to hear something different, Professor Ho's lecture might be a good choice.
reviews.comment_grading:
For this semester, the grading is 15% participation, 25% essay, and 60% final. The participation is mainly depended on how much did you speak in tutorials, so be prepared and read the materials beforehand. The essay topic can be chosen from 6 questions and the length is unlimited, so there's plenty much space for you to elaborate. The final exam is 3 hours long. We had to answer 3 essay questions. But all the questions are related to the lecture, so as long as you listen to lecture carefully, there's not much trouble.
For my personal case, I received B+ for participation and A for the essay, and my final grade is A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is mainly on readings and the essay. The readings are divided into 2 parts, required and optional. The required reading is Immanuel Hsu's 'The Rise of Modern China'. But we don't have to read the whole book for the professor hardly covered half of the events in the book. The optional reading is much heavier, usually one book per topic, but since it's only optional it's up to you to decide if or not to read it.
As for the essay, the workload is really flexible as there's no word limit. People usually write around 3000 words. But there's always diligent students who would write more than 20000 words (in Chinese, though).

reviews.author: mx.ty
reviews.title: If you like chinese history, choose it ! You will not regret
reviews.comment_content: It teaches Chinese History from the Qing Dynasty to the form of The People's Republic of China. It talks about different historical events in this period of time in detail. If you studied Chinese History as one of your electives in secondary school, you will understand more about what he is talking about in class. If not, you might need to read the reading materials or search for more information online.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is absolutely a good teacher. He is very willing to answer your questions in every class. (p.s. there's a Q&A section before the class ends) He speaks English very well and loud that you can hear him. He will hold some discussions and interact with students in class. (p.s. He combined the lecture and tutorial together, so tbh no tutorial) He will post videos on canvas so you can watch them again it if you didn't understand. However, the bad point is no words on the ppt, you need to be focused and joint notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Attendance and engagement
40% Document assignments
10% Exam question submission
40% Final examination

1st document assignment: 86/100
2nd document assignment: Did not show
Exam question submission: 46/50
Final examination: Did not show

Course grade: B-
(I don't know did my 2nd assignment and final exam fail or not. bruh)
reviews.comment_workload:
He did not take attendance in every class, just sometimes.

There are two document assignments
word limit: Max 1000 words.
Both of them are not that easy, you need to read the materials very detail or find historical sources.

Exam question submission is so easy, you just think of 3 MCs and 2 IDs (with answers). When you submitted it, you already get 30 basic marks.

The final Examination included 10 MCs (20%), 7 or 10 choose 5 IDs (30%) [I forgot], 5 choose 2 short questions (20%) and 3 choose 1 LQs (30%).
ID needs to write around 200 words.

reviews.title: Ok la
reviews.comment_content:
The course will begin with an exploration of historical development in the Qing, covering the expansion and consolidation of Manchu rule, and then discuss the impact and legacy of both foreign intrusion and domestic instability in the 19th century and the long shadows they cast on the 20th century.

L1:What is â€œmodernâ€ anyway?
L2:The High Qing
L3:The Manchus
L4:China Marches West
L5:Enjoying the Grand Canal

reviews.comment_teaching:
Fair. There are only pictures on the power point. You need to be extremely focus if you want to know what he is talking about. It will be very exhausted if you only have little knowledge about Chinese history.
The good thing is he usually gives high marks for the assignments. And cheat sheet is allowed for the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Attendance and engagement
He just take the attendance once.

40% Document assignments
The topics of the two assignments: The issue of Manchu identity, The concept of "modern"
The mean of the assignments are very high.

10% Exam question submission
Marks will be given if you submit it.
He required 3 multiple choice questions and 2 ID questions for the exam question submission

40% Final examination
I think the overall grading is mostly base on the performance of your final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy. You only need to submit 3 assignments in total and revise for the final exam. I think you can just read the required reading materials.

reviews.comment_teaching: The whole classes are quite interesting as the content not just focus on the history itself but dig into the meaning behind every events. Lawrence is a gentle and funny professor. And when we meet some proper nouns that are difficult to understand, he always give explanation in Mandarin and Cantonese. So, it's quite friendly to year 1 students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Evaluation:
10% Attendance and participation
40% Document assignments
10% Exam question submission
40% Final examination
As our TA was trapped in mainland China, we don't take attendance this semester. And the course will provide recordings which lead to the situation that students become less and less. I just absented a few classes but it's easy to catch up through the recordings.
About the assignments, I think once you have adequate preparation of documents, and have some unique ideas, it's easy to get a nice score.
About the final exam, it's quite easy for those with foundation of history learning. Just test for some details about the events and the meaning behind these events. All these were taught or discussed in the classes. If you are too lazy to get up for classes at 9 a.m., just watch all the recordings carefully before the exam.
The grade is quite reasonable.

1st assignment: High95 Mean81.1
2nd assignment: High96 Mean84
Exam question submission:High50 Mean41.6
Final exam: unknown

My grade:  I've got 93 in 1st assignment, 86 in 2nd assignment, and 46 in exam question submission.
The grade of final exam is unknown, but I have do adequate preparation and feel very well during the exam. I think my grade in final should be pretty good.

Total grade:A
reviews.comment_workload:
2 big assignments
1 final exam question submission
MANY MANY readings.(But I just read a few of them. I think it doesn't really matter. Just read those he emphasizes in the classes.)
I think the workload is ok.

reviews.author: balalalalalala
reviews.comment_content:
If you have studied Chinese Hisotry before then it will be very easy for you to understand the whole stuff (just to translate)
the course is from the Qing dynasty to the 60s-70s. It was the same content of Part B in the DSE Chinese history syllabus.
it will be much better and clear if you have your Chinese history book with you when you are studying this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
there are many pictures in the ppt, not much words (just a few)
you need to be super careful in listening to it.
the accent is clear and easy to understand.
As the professor is a Hongkonger, he sometimes do provide a Chinese term for you to understand the whole thing.
reviews.comment_grading:
the grading is a bit confused especially to those who study DSE before.
in order to get a good score, you cannot write it in a DSE way.
I got 2 below mean score in the essays, yet it turns out a B+. Maybe I was above mean in the finals.

By the way, as the professor does not have a TA, the participation marks were not counted this time. Not sure if it will be counted in the following terms.
reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is not that much if you start your essay earlier.
in the two essays, you need to set a question by yourself and it will be difficult if you do not have k knowledge of Chinese history.

this course also required much reading. you need to make sure you have enough time to read it as the teaching and the reading materials are not the same.

reviews.author: Loner
reviews.title: Modern China history, especially shows the instructor's viewpoints
reviews.comment_content: This general history course critically surveys selected topics of major political, social, and cultural events and characters in China from the late-Qing period to the eve of the People's Republic of China (circa the 1800s-1940s). The reference book is The Rise of Modern China by Immanuel HsÃ¼.
reviews.comment_teaching: No PowerPoint, the professor usually just speaks out his comments on historical events. If you don't know any basic knowledge, it will be hard for you to catch up with the lecture. Sometimes his analysis and comments are kind of interesting. He often uses the point of view of the reference book, sometimes agrees with that and sometimes disagrees. Tutorials are based on the reading of the reference book. Most are the discussion for students to share their points.
reviews.comment_grading:
No attendance for lectures but not for tutorials.
3. Final project or examination: 60% (2 essays selected by 5 questions given to you, open-book exam, either Chinese or English are workable.)
I've got a B-.
reviews.comment_workload: Reading materials should be read before the tutorials because the discussions are based on the contents of the book. Professor's viewpoints in lectures are sometimes needed to be taken down, which are useful for the final eassy-writing. No other workload in addition to these

reviews.author: ç§‘å¤§è–¯ä»”
reviews.title: Light workload course
reviews.comment_content:
Topics of Lecture

Weeks 1-2: Introduction and organization of the course + China before the Opium War  

Weeks 3-4: The Opium War (Official narratives and their problems)

Weeks 5-6: Foreign Invasion of China (Bible, guns and money)

Week 7: Reforms (Weaknesses exaggerated, success under-rated)

Weeks 8-9: Revolution, Republic, and Warlords (Doom and boom)

Weeks 9-10: Rise of Nationalism (Double-edge sword)  

Weeks 11-12: â€œFascistâ€ KMT versus â€œRighteousâ€ CCP (Rhetoric versus reality)      

Week 13: The Second Sino-Japanese War (Issues and controversies) (and a little bit of Civil War if time allows)
reviews.comment_teaching: He didn't teach well. The most important thing is that he didn't prepare PowerPoint slides for the students, it would be difficult for those diligent students to revise after lessons. Most importantly, he mostly repeated what he had taught in the previous lessons, so he could not teach all the things eventually. That's why I skipped most lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading of Professor Ho was not bad. I didn't take Chinese history in secondary school, but I secured a B+ in this subject, so I am quite satisfied with that already. I could say the reasons why I received such grade is mostly contributed to the special arrangements. As the mid-term was canceled, I didn't need to recite a lot of Chinese history stuff, this arrangement would definitely benefit those who were not familiar with Chinese history (in my opinion).
reviews.comment_workload: Due to special arrangements in this semester, the mid-term and tutorial sessions were canceled. Two essays were used to replace the mid-term. Therefore, the workload was extremely light, compared to other courses. What you need to do is to do research on the two topics of your essays and write two 4000 words Chinese essays or English essays in 6000 words each. Yet, these two essays will determine your final grades for this semester.

reviews.author: joy111
reviews.title: WORST CLASS EVER!!!!!
reviews.comment_content: This course tells about the Chinese history. Boring class without ppt illustration or any lecture notes. Basically you have to go to every lecture to actually learn from this course, but attendance is not taken. No tutorial arrangements. I learnt basically nothing.
reviews.comment_teaching: Bad. He teaches so slowly that I am easy to fall asleep. it's hard to grab his main points given that he talks without a clear sequence. You can barely take notes down because you have no idea of what is important.
reviews.comment_grading: Due to the special arrangement of classes of this semester, the grading is based on 2 essays. You can choose among several given topics, and both Chinese and English can be used. However the grading is very bad. We can not acquire the standard of his grading. Eventually this course became my lowest graded course in this semester.
reviews.comment_workload: very light. Since there is no mid term or finals for the course in this semester, there is literally no required reading.

reviews.author: beibeixiaozhu
reviews.comment_content: The content is about Chinese history from 1840s-1949. The professor offered English and Chinese versions for the course, which was convenient for me to read.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor provided some new and careful opinions for the incidents. Although I did not agree with all his views, his proof and argument are meaningful.
reviews.comment_grading: You can either write essays or take midterm and final. These kind of courses are more subjective than the science course, so maybe you find scores confusing. But the paper were judged fairly. I had a high score in midterm, but it did not show final score. I got A-.
reviews.comment_workload: No writing work, but there are some discussions contributed to your grade. Many pages of reading are required every week, unless you read it, it is difficult to catch up with the professor lecture and discussion.

reviews.author: Erica Lee
reviews.comment_content: It's mandatory course for GCS students, and also a common core course, which covers modern Chinese history. However, if you are not interested or haven't learnt Chinese history before, I recommend you to take other courses instead. Also, if you are non-Chinese background student, you will easily get confused with all historical issues and other historical elements.
reviews.comment_teaching: To be honest, I cannot find any good parts of this professor. He sometimes speaks Cantonese in lecture that confuses non-canto speaking students, considering that it's common core course. He does not provide any PPT or notes that you might need to jot down or make voice records for all classes as you will miss out some important points that will appear on exam paper. I would say TAs were very helpful, and they were always willing to help students.
reviews.comment_grading:
The professor's grading scheme isn't strict nor very relaxed. However if you put effort and write as much as you can (especially for essay) he will be very considerate and give you high marks.
However, the professor still haven't released the grade even till now . After taking exam for 3 hours handwriting 4 short essays and 2 long essays for finals, he has never released the grade even till the next semester is about to start, so that you need to wait without knowing when.
reviews.comment_workload: After few weeks, there will be four tutorial courses, and each class covers different issues. Each tutorial requires few chapters of reading, and it's impossible to read them just in one day. I recommend you to jot down some key points so that you know what to discuss with your classmates and TA In tutorial class. Class performance is also part of your grade, and both TAs care about it very much.

reviews.author: vanessalee
reviews.comment_content: Modern China period from Late Qing to Civil War. Readings are mediocre not too much workload. But make sure you are interested if you want to enjoy the readings
reviews.comment_teaching: Poor teaching. Did not attend lessons after midterm. Useless. Lectures not useful to exam at all. Attendance not calculated.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite good. I got A-, with all tutorials attended and actively participated, and 22/25 for midterm.
reviews.comment_workload:
Tutorials, midterm and final exam.
Tutorial - Not really satisfied with having tutorials out of class time. Required to study few texts beforehand and do in class discussion with peers regarding the text and guided discussion questions.
Midterm - 3 short questions and 1 essay question. Marked by TAs therefore quite lenient.
Final - 5/6 short questions and 2 essay questions. Marked by professor. Did not receieve the grade for final essay but still fine if you studied the required readings well.

reviews.author: parkchan
reviews.title: Modern CHina
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers from the decline of Qing dynasty to the establishment of Republic. There are lots of things to remember, but if you have general knowledge on world history, there shouldn't be lots of problem.

I think if you don't like reading, you will have some hard time.

Both mid-term and final are all essay-writing, which final took whole 3 hours of writing.

There are tutorials you must attend every 2 weeks.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Ho speaks good English, but you really need to pay attention to understand what he is saying.

He does not covers all during his lecture. Reading will help you.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is decent; if you have done all the readings, and have memorized them, you can get B-A+ range.

The mid term was 25%, tutorial 15%, and Final 60%

Attendance is only checked on tutorials.
reviews.comment_workload:
No works to hand in, except that there are short presentation and discussion session required for tutorials. But is not that much of work.

There are lots of reading. Without reading you cannot get satisfactory score.

This course is required course for the Global China Studies students.

reviews.author: ching_tc
reviews.comment_content: the content around the chinese history from major event like opium war til the present modern china
reviews.comment_teaching:
slightly boring
but the lecture do not need to take attendance
do not have any IPRS
reviews.comment_grading:
just fair grading, even the workload is not small
i dont really feel like it is a good grade course
reviews.comment_workload:
need to do one long essay around 2to3000 words in chinese or english which is optional, slightly hard for people who have never really come across with the chinese history subjects previously
only final exam and essayx1

reviews.author: chimz
reviews.comment_content:
History of modern china (from 1830s, pre opium war to 1920s students' movements)

Analysis from Prof. Ho is entirely different from the text required by Immanuel Hsu.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching of Prof. Ho is boring because of his flat voice. I don't know why he always blames others.
4 tutorial sessions conducted by TA are excellent. Concrete examples were given. Mr. Kent Yeung gave enough guidance for our term paper as well.
reviews.comment_grading: No explanation or comments given after marking all papers. I have no idea why I got B-.
reviews.comment_workload:
20% Participation (take attendance during tutorial sessions only but not lectures; don't skip tutorial sessions and try to be more active in tutorial session in order to have good impression.)

30% term paper (can be individual or a group, max. 3 people in one group; research title should be set by week 6)

50% final exam (3 hours; 3 essay type questions; 1 of out 6 short question takes up 10 marks; 2 out of 9 long questions take up 40 marks)

No mid-term exam or quizzes

reviews.author: lcyk
reviews.comment_content:
Dse hist + chist
Try to find out the main theme of the course then u can ace ur final.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ok la. He is a nice guy who is willing to spend time wf u to discuss abt ur work. Heard some classmates said tht they can't find the mainpt in each of his lsns
reviews.comment_grading:
I got highest for two essays, 46/50 for the exam questions submission. Final dunno but I think I elaborated things well.

At last: A+

(fyi, I only read few of his assigned readings for the asm then had some consultations wf him. I skip all classes and ignore rest of the readings. However, I spent 4 days without sleeping to revise dse chist and hist for the final.)
reviews.comment_workload:
Two essays, one exam questions submission and final exam

Essays may be hard for yr1 students to get a good grade cos u have to guess what the prof really wants. He asked us to set the topic by ourselves but ofc it's hard to set a good topic that he likes.

Exam questions submission is ez, just follow his instructions.

For the final exam, there's 10 mc, 5 identification questions, 2 short questions and 1 long question. If you have studied Chist and Hist, it wont be hard for u.

reviews.title: HUMA 1440
reviews.comment_content:
The content itself is interesting once you get the flow.
It is important to follow up with assigned reading.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sometimes boring and sometimes fun.
He does not use any ppt, and barely used LMES/Canvas, you only have your in-class notes and assigned reading to study with.
Professor would explain events in detail, which helps to get the entire idea, so I suggest writing down somewhat detailed note.
reviews.comment_grading:
NO attendance
No homework
No reading check

Only one project (term paper)
final exam, and tutorial attendance and participation
I suggest participating well in tutorial
and try to start the term paper soon (better to finish before the exam period)

Also, study ahead for final, no midterm-> more on final

The grading was not bad
reviews.comment_workload:
Only one final term paper
-this assignment was assigned way before the due date
(I believe most did it at the last minute)
Just one Final exam
- essay exam
